newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: U.S. Africa hand Crocker recommends transparency.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Africa hand Crocker recommends transparency.

text.p: Chester Crocker, a former U.S. assistant secretary of state for Africa, urged southern African nations on Wednesday to fight corruption and ditch Marxism.

"Neither local or foeign investors will have the confidence to risk their capital if they perceive that awards and contracts are warped by political favouritism or improper dealings," Crocker told a trade and investment summit for southern Africa.
"In the absence of a level playing field, they will look elsewhere or sit on their hands."
Crocker said the policy climate for economic growth in the region had improved significantly, but implementation of new programmes was still hesitant and slow.
"The removal of barriers is a slow process, especially in the field of trade," he said.
Crocker praised efforts by southern African states to liberalise their economies, but said some political leaders were still hobbled by Marxist leanings.
"There are some remaining political dinosaurs who, for reasons of pride, nostalgia and self-interest, cling to old visions," he said.
